title: Decision support tools
text:
Smart City’s brain


The Back-end
The heuristics, logic, and models.

The Front-end
Dashboards, visualizations, and stakeholder apps.


GOAL
To reduce the “Cognitive Load”
without oversimplifying the “Wicked” reality.



Remind them of the “Brain” analogy. A brain is useless if it can’t move the body.
Decision Support Tools are the nervous system. They take the data from our models and present it so a Mayor, a Planner, or a Citizen can say “If we do X, then Y happens.”
Crucial point: A good DST doesn’t hide complexity; it manages it.

title: Decision support tools
text:
Dashboard’s Anathomy


Indicators
The “Vital Signs” of the city (Air quality, traffic flow, energy use).

“What-If” Engine
Moving from static data to interactive simulation.

Contextual Narratives
Data is meaningless without the “Story” of the place.



Refer to your Data Viz notes: “Identifying patterns, trends, and outliers.”
In an urban context, a dashboard shouldn’t just be a “report card” of the past. It should be a “flight simulator” for the future.
Example: A dashboard that shows current CO2 levels is a viz; a dashboard that lets you “delete” a parking lot and see the CO2 drop in real-time is a Decision Support Tool.

title: Decision support tools
text:
The “Misleading” Interface


Aesthetic Trap
Just because a dashboard is “shiny” or 3D doesn’t mean it’s accurate.

Truncated Realities
What is not being measured? (e.g., social capital, happiness).

Cognitive Biases
How “Visual Narratives” can accidentally (or intentionally) nudge decisions the wrong way.



Connect this to your Viz Pitfalls: “Misleading graphs, improper scaling.”
In Smart Cities, there is a risk of “Technological Solutionism.” If it’s on a high-res screen, people tend to believe it’s “The Truth.”
As curators of these tools, the students must ensure the visualization doesn’t lie about the model’s uncertainty.

title: Decision support tools
text:
Who is the Pilot?


High-Level Ops
Real-time management (Emergency response, traffic control).

Strategic Planning
10–20 year horizons (Housing, Climate adaptation).

Public Participation
Transparency and “Co-design” with citizens.


Different users need different “Front-ends.”
A technician needs a “Technical” viz. A citizen needs a “Human-centric” viz.
Workshop II Preview: We will look at how to tailor your “Wicked Problem” map into a tool that a specific stakeholder can actually use to make a choice.

Workshop I: Mapping Your Wicked Problem

Start by managing expectations: Today we move from theory to logic to practice.
Part I is the ‘Why’ (Complexity) and the ‘How’ (The 4 Heuristics). It sets the conceptual stage.
Part II is the ‘Deep Dive’. We get hands-on with System Dynamics logic to help them deconstruct the specific course assignments they are working on.
Part III links the “Brain” back to reality: How does this logic serve stakeholders and talk to data?

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The City = Complex Systems

A city is decomposable into semi-predictable parts.
It is a dynamic process of organized complexity.
The Smart City Paradox:

We have new technical capabilities (Big Data, sensors, AI).
But they rely on modelling techniques devised decades ago to solve social problems.




The city is the ultimate complex system.
“Smart” doesn’t mean “New.” Many of the algorithms we use today were born in the 1960s and 70s to address social housing, transport equity, and urban decay. The technology has caught up to the theory, but the focus remains social.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Complexity alive




To a computer or a traditional top-down planner, this looks like total disorder. But it isn’t. It is a highly efficient, self-organizing system where thousands of individual decisions create a functional flow. This is the ‘organized complexity’ Jane Jacobs spoke about—and it is exactly what we struggle to represent in a static model.”

title: Systems Thinking
section: What the Smart City is NOT
text:
What the Smart City is NOT

It is not a crystal ball for perfect prediction.
It is not a digital twin that is the reality.
The Map is not the Territory:

Models are simplified representations.
In a complex system, “Total Control” is an illusion.
We model to understand potentiality, not to dictate outcomes.




models are fallible.
Because of urban complexity (non-linearity and emergence), we can’t predict exactly what a city will do.
“The Answer,” they are misrepresenting what a model is. It’s a tool for exploration, not a decree.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Science of Cities



“…cities must now be looked at as constellations of interactions, communications, relations, flows, and networks rather … than locations […] location is, in effect, a synthesis of interactions.”
— Michael Batty, 2013





Use this to transition into the modeling heuristics. If location is just a “synthesis of interactions,” then to model a city, we shouldn’t just map where things are (static), but how things move and relate (dynamic). This justifies why we look at things like Networks and Agent-Based models.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Organized Complexity
Jane Jacobs


Cities are not:

Problems of Simplicity
Problems of Disorganized Complexity (millions of random variables).


They are problems of Organized Complexity:

A huge number of factors which are interrelated into an organic whole.



Jane Jacobs (1961) borrowed this term from Warren Weaver. Explain the difference: - Simplicity: A falling stone (gravity). - Disorganized: A gas (billions of atoms behaving randomly). - Organized: A city or a living cell. Everything depends on everything else. If you change the park (social), you change the crime rate (social), which changes the property value (economic), which changes the transport needs (technical).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Interconnection of Parts

“The city is not a work of art… the city is a process.” – J.Jacobs


It is a Bottom-Up system.
Small, local interactions \(\rightarrow\) Large, global patterns.


Highlight that both Jane Jacobs and Christopher Alexander saw the “interconnection of parts” as the central issue. For the students’ projects: Tell them that when they model a “Smart City” intervention, they aren’t just adding a “part” to a machine; they are intervening in a “living process” that will react in unpredictable ways.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Complexity Science
The Reductionist Shortcut:

A mental habit of breaking the city into isolated “parts” to make it easier to manage.

The Complexity Reality:

Science not of the “atoms” (buildings, roads, people), but of the connections between them.


Cross-Scale Interactions

Single street-level decisions ripples up to the metropolitan scale.



“Reductionism is a form of mental lazy gymnastics. Our brains are hardwired to simplify: we see a ‘housing problem’ or a ‘transport problem’ as separate buckets because it’s cognitively cheaper to process.” - But cities don’t work in buckets. Complexity science is about the ‘glue’—the flows and communications that Michael Batty mentioned. - Emphasize that we aren’t studying the ‘atoms’ (the physical objects) but the ‘chemistry’ (how they react when they touch). This is why the ‘Brain’ of the city needs to be a systems-thinking brain, not just a spreadsheet of isolated parts.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Systems


Complex

Adaptive relationships.
Emergent outcomes.
More than the sum of its parts.


Complicated

Fixed relationships.
Predictable outcomes.
The sum of its parts.


   

A Boeing 747 is complicated; it’s difficult to understand, but it’s reliable and linear. A city is complex; it is alive. In a complicated system, if you remove a part, you just have a broken machine. In a complex system, if you remove a part, the system adapts or collapses entirely.

title: Systems Thinking
section: The City is not a Tree
text:
The City is not a Tree


“It is for this reason - because the mind’s first function is to reduce the ambiguity and overlap in a confusing situation … it is endowed with a basic intolerance for ambiguity - that structures like the city, which do require overlapping sets within them, are nevertheless persistently conceived as trees.” – Christooher Alexander

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Systems Thinking 101


Systems Thinking
Seeing the Web of interactions

Linear Thinking
A \(\rightarrow\) B (Cause and Effect)


FOCUS ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PARTS
NOT JUST PARTS THEMSELVES.


Contrast the two ways of thinking. Linear thinking says: “Traffic is bad, widen the road.” Systems thinking asks: “If I widen the road, how does that change land use, and how does that eventually bring more cars back (induced demand)?” This is the fundamental shift required for the rest of the lecture.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Modeling as a Heuristic
A model is not “The Truth.”
It is a Heuristic: a mental shortcut or tool for discovery.


“All models are wrong, but some are useful” (George Box).



This is a friendly way to lower the “technical” barrier. You aren’t asking them to be data scientists today; you are asking them to use models as “thinking tools” to simplify a reality that is too complex to hold in their heads all at once.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Smart City’s brain


The Back-end
The heuristics, logic, and models.

The Front-end
Dashboards, visualizations, and stakeholder apps.


Logic must precede display.


Use the “Brain” analogy to ground the lecture. The “Front-end” is what people see (the dashboard), but the “Brain” is the modeling logic we are discussing today. If the logic (the model) is flawed, the visualization is just “fancy misinformation.” Today is about building the intellectual back-end.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Dimensions
of most urban logic modelling



SPATIAL
RELATIONAL

TEMPORAL
SYSTEMIC

title: Systems Thinking
text:
1. The Spatial Dimension

The Logic of “Where”: Focuses on geometry, distance, and density.
Key Question: How does the physical arrangement of assets (buildings, parks, roads) determine urban performance?
Core Concept: Social Physics. Just like gravity, “mass” (high-density jobs or housing) exerts a pull on the surrounding area.


Spatial logic is the traditional bread and butter of planning. It’s about the map. It assumes that proximity equals interaction.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
2. The Relational Dimension

The Logic of “Connection”: Focuses on topology and network hierarchy.
Key Question: How is the city “wired”? Is it about how far you are in meters, or how many turns you are from the main network?
Core Concept: Graph Theory. The city as nodes and edges.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
3. The Temporal Dimension

The Logic of “When”: Focuses on change, evolution, and path dependency.
Key Question: How did the city get here, and how fast is it changing?
Core Concept: Dynamics. Recognizing that an urban intervention today might take 10 years to show its true impact (delays).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
4. The Systemic Dimension

The Logic of “Why”: Focuses on causality and interdependencies.
Key Question: What are the unintended consequences? If we improve transport, does it inadvertently raise rents and displace the people it was meant to help?
Core Concept: Feedback Loops. Circular causality where an output of a system becomes an input for the next cycle.

only some…

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Land-Use Transport
LUTI ### The Anatomy

Primary Dimensions: Spatial (High) + Relational (Medium).
The Engine: Spatial Interaction Models. Uses gravity equations to find a state of “Equilibrium” between where people live, where they work, and how they travel.
Input/Output: Zonal data (population/jobs) Predicted traffic flows and land-use shifts.



LUTI is the “Strategic Planner’s” model.
It assumes the city seeks a balance. If you reduce travel time to the city center, the ‘brain’ of this model calculates that property values will rise.
It is great for long-term infrastructure but often misses “sudden” social shifts.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Land-Use Transport
eg. Predicting the impact of a new Metro line on residential density in a suburban area.


Pros
Excellent for long-term strategic planning and infrastructure “stress testing.”

Cons
Highly aggregate (treats people as masses) and mostly static (ignores the “chaos” of daily life).


What it lacks: Temporal and Systemic feedback. It assumes a city is a puzzle that can be “solved” into a perfect balance.



LUTI is the “Strategic Planner’s” model.
It assumes the city seeks a balance. If you reduce travel time to the city center, the ‘brain’ of this model calculates that property values will rise.
It is great for long-term infrastructure but often misses “sudden” social shifts.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Network Models
eg. Space Syntax
The Anatomy

Primary Dimensions: Relational (High) + Spatial (Low).
The Engine: Topological Analysis. It measures “Integration” (how accessible a street is) and “Choice” (how likely a street is to be used as a shortcut).
Input/Output: Street centerlines Heatmaps of predicted pedestrian and vehicular movement.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Network Models
NM ### Example & Critique

Example: Redesigning a town center to increase footfall for local shops by improving topological connectivity.
Pros: Very high correlation with real-world human movement; requires minimal data (just the map).
Cons: Can be “blind” to land use. It might predict high movement on a street that is topologically central but has no reason for people to go there.
What it lacks: Systemic “Attractors.” It prioritizes the shape of the container over the content inside it.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Dynamics
SD ### The Anatomy

Primary Dimensions: Temporal (High) + Systemic (High).
The Engine: Stocks and Flows. Uses differential equations to model how quantities (e.g., housing stock) change over time based on rates of change (e.g., construction rate).
Input/Output: Causal variables Policy “flight simulators” showing 20-year trajectories.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Dynamics
Example & Critique

Example: Modeling how a city-wide “Air Quality Zone” affects car ownership and public health over two decades.
Pros: Unrivaled for identifying “Levers”—small changes that lead to massive systemic shifts.
Cons: Non-spatial. It can tell you how much change will happen, but it cannot tell you where on the map it will happen.
What it lacks: Spatial Granularity. It treats the whole city as one big “bucket” of variables.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models
ABM & Celullar Automata (CA)
The Anatomy

Primary Dimensions: Spatial (High) + Systemic (High) + Temporal (High).
The Engine: Bottom-up Micro-simulation. Individual “Agents” are given simple rules. The city’s patterns “Emerge” from thousands of these local interactions.
Input/Output: Behavioral rules Emergent patterns (e.g., segregation, traffic jams, or urban sprawl).


Visit https://softologyblog.wordpress.com/category/agent-based-modeling/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models
Example & Critique

Example: Simulating how individual shoppers choose between a physical high street and online delivery during a pandemic.
Pros: Captures “Emergence” and “Surprise”—the unintended side effects of human behavior.
Cons: Extremely “noisy” and computationally expensive. Small errors in individual rules lead to massive distortions.
What it lacks: Predictive Certainty. Because it’s stochastic (random), it gives you a range of possibilities rather than a single “right” answer.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The “Wicked” Problem

Urban challenges are not puzzles (with one right answer).
They are Wicked Problems:

They are interconnected: solving one creates another.
They have no “stopping rule” or perfect solution.
They are better or worse, not right or wrong.



Refer to Rittel and Webber’s definition 1973. Explain that in a smart city context, we often try to “optimize” things. But a city isn’t a machine to be optimized; it’s a wicked problem to be managed. For their assignments: help them see that their chosen problem (e.g., housing or pollution) is “wicked” because it’s tied to a dozen other factors.
Key Characteristics of Wicked Problems:

No definitive formulation: The problem itself is hard to define.
No “stopping rule”: There’s no clear point at which you know it’s solved.
Solutions aren’t true/false: They are only “good” or “bad,” not objectively correct.
Irreversible consequences: Every attempt to solve it has lasting impacts, making “trials count”.
Interconnectedness: Solving one part often creates or reveals other problems.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Setting the Boundary
A model is only as good as what you leave out. * Endogenous: Factors the system controls. * Exogenous: Factors outside our influence (the “Environment”).

The Challenge: If you draw the boundary too small, you miss the “Wicked” side-effects.



This is the most important part of the workshop.
Use the “Ecological Footprint” example from your references: London’s boundary isn’t the M25 motorway; its “resource boundary” is the whole world.
Tell students: “Decide today what is inside your ‘Brain’ and what is just ‘Noise’ from the outside.”

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Archetypes

Balancing & LimitsUnintended FeedbackResource & Power Loops



Limits to Growth: A tech-hub grows fast until housing prices drive out the talent, hitting a plateau.
Eroding Goals: Reducing environmental targets because the current infrastructure “cannot handle” the cost of meeting them.
Growth and Underinvestment: Demand for public transit grows, but the city delays purchasing new trains, leading to a collapse in service quality.




Fixes that Fail: Widening a road to fix traffic leads to “induced demand,” creating more traffic than before.
Shifting the Burden: Using temporary “band-aid” repairs on aging water pipes instead of replacing the fundamental infrastructure.
Escalation: Two neighboring districts compete to offer the lowest taxes to attract firms, eventually bankrupting their own public services.




Tragedy of the Commons: Unregulated groundwater extraction by individual buildings leading to the sinking of the entire city’s foundation.
Success to the Successful: High-income neighborhoods receive the best schools, which increases property values and further concentrates educational funding there.
Accidental Adversaries: A transit agency and a housing department both try to optimize their own KPIs, but end up blocking each other’s long-term goals.






Learning to recognize “The Classics” of urban failure.
Remind students that these are diagnostic tools.
They don’t describe a specific problem, but a family of problems.
Use these tabs to ask the groups: “Which of these ‘Classics’ best describes the wicked problem you are mapping today?”.

title: Course Guide
text:
Content
This course introduces students to the concepts, technologies, governance models, and socio-spatial implications of Smart Cities. It critically examines how digital technologies, data, and urban analytics are applied to address urban challenges such as sustainability, mobility, climate adaptation, inclusion and quality of life. Through a project-based approach, students work in groups to analyse a real or simulated urban case, develop a Smart Cities solution, and reflect on ethical, social and governance dimensions. In this course, the student will gain fundamental theoretical and practical knowledge to understand smart cities, including the relationship to the sustainability debate applies knowledge and skills to a real-life case study involving local communities in the indicator analysis, development of Smart City planning solutions and policy recommendations for the built environment. Be able to critically reflect on Smart City concepts and communicate the results of Smart City strategies to stakeholders. This course utilises acquired knowledge from previous and parallel running courses, such as the advanced methods course, ethics in research, data analysis in GIS, and urban policies, and adds to it the component of smart sustainable cities and the human factor.

title: Interview questions
text:
I’ve spent the last decade at the intersection of data science and the built environment. Early on, I realized that while infrastructure is static, human behavior is dynamic. This led me to the Space Syntax approach—essentially using data-driven, graph-based analysis to understand multi-scale networks. It allowed me to bridge the gap between rigorous academic theory and the practical realities of urban consultancy.
In terms of technical scale, my experience is quite broad. I’ve managed everything from high-frequency IoT sensor data for real-time indoor movement to architecting the tracking of entire city bus networks modelling scenarios. I’ve applied these insights to everything from local ‘urban acupuncture’ strategies to large-scale masterplans, always focusing on how we can use data to measure social benefits. My work has taken me across the globe—from Colombia to Australia, London, and now Madrid—which has given me a deep appreciation for the cultural nuances required to work effectivily with multinational teams.
Inevitably, working on European urban development leads you to the Net-Zero agenda. Most recently, in 2024, I led a team of eight researchers at the Norman Foster Institute to develop the Climate Action Plan for Athens. This was a major milestone where we had to harmonize environmental data,set plans for reaching carbon emission targets, and greening strategies into a compliant, actionable policy framework.
This work led me to what I call my ‘professional obsession’: the link between environmental quality and human health outcomes. I’ve realized that the environment—whether it’s air quality, climate resilience, or the built landscape—is the primary driver of health inequalities. Over the last year, I’ve been focusing on quantifying these links, moving from spectral analysis of country-wide information to advising on transport initiatives that prioritize health outcomes. I want to move beyond just ‘collecting data’ to reducing the environmental inequalities that impact people’s lives.
That brings me here. I see this role at the EEA as the ideal next frontier. It’s the one place where I can combine data at scale, health implications, and European policy. I’ve spent my career ‘forcing’ these elements to meet, and I’m eager to bring that integrated perspective to the Agency’s monitoring and evidence-gathering mission.



There are three primary reasons why I am sitting here today, ranging from the Agency’s unique mandate to the urgency of our current environmental timeline.

The Unique Intersection of Science and Policy First, from an institutional perspective, the EEA is unparalleled. There is truly no other organization in the world where high-level science, legislative policy, and ground-level implementation meet with such a rigorous and independent point of view. For a data professional, the opportunity to work within the Eionet framework—translating raw monitoring data into the evidence base that literally steers the European Green Deal—is the highest possible application of my skillset.
The Urgency of the Mission Second, on a personal level, I cannot think of a human challenge more pressing than the climate and biodiversity crisis. We saw in the State of the Environment Report (SOER) that while our frameworks are robust, far too few of our targets are currently on track for 2030. This reality doesn’t discourage me; it focuses me. I want to be part of the ‘course correction,’ using data to identify exactly where we are lagging and how we can accelerate progress toward climate neutrality.
The Scale of the Challenge Finally, I am genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the challenge. Moving from urban-scale projects to a pan-European monitoring mandate is a significant leap, but it is one I feel prepared for. I am at a stage in my career where I want to contribute at the highest level possible. I am confident that my experience in harmonizing fragmented data across borders and my focus on health outcomes can provide the Agency with the ‘connective tissue’ needed to turn complex monitoring into actionable policy insights.




I view stress not as an individual burden to be hidden, but as a signal to recalibrate our collective focus. My approach to high-pressure situations—such as a tight reporting deadline for a major EEA indicator—is built on three pillars:

Above all, I am a team player. When pressure mounts, I believe in absolute transparency with my peers. I don’t ‘hide’ from the stress; I bring it to the table so we can address it together. By fostering a supportive environment early on, I ensure that when a crisis hits, the team feels comfortable speaking up about bottlenecks before they become failures.
(‘Project First’ Mindset) My first instinct in a stressed scenario is to shift the focus from individual tasks to the overall project objective. I lead the team in a rapid prioritization exercise—identifying ‘must-haves’ versus ‘nice-to-haves’ and playing to each person’s strengths. It’s an ‘all hands on deck’ approach where we reallocate resources dynamically to ensure the core mission is met, even if it means shifting secondary individual goals.
(Proactive Mentorship and Support Networks) I am a firm believer in keeping close mentors and a professional support network. I don’t wait for a crisis to build these relationships. By maintaining regular contact with mentors, I have a ‘ready-to-go’ sounding board when stress hits. This means I can get high-level advice or a second opinion quickly, without needing a full debrief of the situation, allowing for faster decision-making under pressure.

In short, I manage stress by converting it into structured team action. This ensures that the quality of our evidence remains high, even when the timeline is short.



I’ve had a very rewarding journey in my current position, and I am proud of the milestones our team has achieved. However, I have reached a professional ceiling where the nature of the work no longer aligns with where I want to make an impact. I am moving toward this role for three main reasons:

Moving from Advice to Implementation and Tracking In consultancy, you often advise up to a certain point, but because there is sometimes a lack of regulatory follow-through on proposals, it is difficult to ensure those suggestions have a sustained, long-term life. I no longer want to just ‘drop’ a project and move to the next; I want to be part of an institution that has the mandate for the long-term monitoring and tracking of those initiatives. I want to see the evidence loop close.
Seeking a Long-Term Institutional Vision I am looking for a professional environment with a 10- or 20-year horizon, rather than a 6-month project cycle. The EEA’s mission to provide the evidence base for the European Green Deal offers that stability and vision. I want to dedicate my skills to one cohesive, long-term plan where the data I architect today informs policy assessments a decade from now.
Giving Back and Team Growth I leave my current role on excellent terms. I’ve learned an immense amount, built lasting professional relationships, and found great fulfillment in up-skilling my colleagues and mentoring junior researchers. However, to continue my own growth as an expert in environmental health and data architecture, I need to be in a place where the scale of the challenge matches the scale of the European mission.

Closing Statement: Essentially, I’m not running away from my current role; I am running toward the responsibility and the long-term accountability that comes with being an Expert at the EEA.
Here is your consolidated EEA Interview Cheat Sheet. This Markdown is designed to be your “Source of Truth.” You can print this out or keep it on a secondary screen during your interview to ensure your narrative hits every institutional and technical requirement.





The Journey: Architect (Bogotá) → Space Syntax/Networks (UCL/London) → Geospatial Data Architect (Global).
The Languages: Spanish (Native), English (Fluent), French (Fluent), Portuguese (Advanced). Key for Eionet coordination.
The Pivot: Shifting focus to Environmental Health (prevention over cure) and linking urban morphology to climate resilience.
The “Why”: Transitioning from Consultancy (Advising) to EEA (Shaping/Implementing). I want to contribute to the “Gold Standard” of European data and help “Course Correct” the 2030 Climate Action Plan.
The Stack: Reportnet 3.0 (Modern, cloud-native reporting), Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS), and the SDI (Spatial Data Infrastructure).
Key Themes: Human Health & Environment; Circular Economy; Data & Digitalization.

title: Interview questions
text:
I’ve spent the last decade at the intersection of data science and the built environment. Early on, I realized that while infrastructure is static, human behavior is dynamic. This led me to the Space Syntax approach—essentially using data-driven, graph-based analysis to understand multi-scale networks. It allowed me to bridge the gap between rigorous academic theory and the practical realities of urban consultancy.
In terms of technical scale, my experience is quite broad. I’ve managed everything from high-frequency IoT sensor data for real-time indoor movement to architecting the tracking of entire city bus networks modelling scenarios. I’ve applied these insights to everything from local ‘urban acupuncture’ strategies to large-scale masterplans, always focusing on how we can use data to measure social benefits. My work has taken me across the globe—from Colombia to Australia, London, and now Madrid—which has given me a deep appreciation for the cultural nuances required to work effectivily with multinational teams.
Inevitably, working on European urban development leads you to the Net-Zero agenda. Most recently, in 2024, I led a team of eight researchers at the Norman Foster Institute to develop the Climate Action Plan for Athens. This was a major milestone where we had to harmonize environmental data,set plans for reaching carbon emission targets, and greening strategies into a compliant, actionable policy framework.
This work led me to what I call my ‘professional obsession’: the link between environmental quality and human health outcomes. I’ve realized that the environment—whether it’s air quality, climate resilience, or the built landscape—is the primary driver of health inequalities. Over the last year, I’ve been focusing on quantifying these links, moving from spectral analysis of country-wide information to advising on transport initiatives that prioritize health outcomes. I want to move beyond just ‘collecting data’ to reducing the environmental inequalities that impact people’s lives.
That brings me here. I see this role at the EEA as the ideal next frontier. It’s the one place where I can combine data at scale, health implications, and European policy. I’ve spent my career ‘forcing’ these elements to meet, and I’m eager to bring that integrated perspective to the Agency’s monitoring and evidence-gathering mission.

title: Interview questions
text:
There are three primary reasons why I am sitting here today, ranging from the Agency’s unique mandate to the urgency of our current environmental timeline.

The Unique Intersection of Science and Policy First, from an institutional perspective, the EEA is unparalleled. There is truly no other organization in the world where high-level science, legislative policy, and ground-level implementation meet with such a rigorous and independent point of view. For a data professional, the opportunity to work within the Eionet framework—translating raw monitoring data into the evidence base that literally steers the European Green Deal—is the highest possible application of my skillset.
The Urgency of the Mission Second, on a personal level, I cannot think of a human challenge more pressing than the climate and biodiversity crisis. We saw in the State of the Environment Report (SOER) that while our frameworks are robust, far too few of our targets are currently on track for 2030. This reality doesn’t discourage me; it focuses me. I want to be part of the ‘course correction,’ using data to identify exactly where we are lagging and how we can accelerate progress toward climate neutrality.
The Scale of the Challenge Finally, I am genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the challenge. Moving from urban-scale projects to a pan-European monitoring mandate is a significant leap, but it is one I feel prepared for. I am at a stage in my career where I want to contribute at the highest level possible. I am confident that my experience in harmonizing fragmented data across borders and my focus on health outcomes can provide the Agency with the ‘connective tissue’ needed to turn complex monitoring into actionable policy insights.

title: Interview questions
text:
I view stress not as an individual burden to be hidden, but as a signal to recalibrate our collective focus. My approach to high-pressure situations—such as a tight reporting deadline for a major EEA indicator—is built on three pillars:

Above all, I am a team player. When pressure mounts, I believe in absolute transparency with my peers. I don’t ‘hide’ from the stress; I bring it to the table so we can address it together. By fostering a supportive environment early on, I ensure that when a crisis hits, the team feels comfortable speaking up about bottlenecks before they become failures.
(‘Project First’ Mindset) My first instinct in a stressed scenario is to shift the focus from individual tasks to the overall project objective. I lead the team in a rapid prioritization exercise—identifying ‘must-haves’ versus ‘nice-to-haves’ and playing to each person’s strengths. It’s an ‘all hands on deck’ approach where we reallocate resources dynamically to ensure the core mission is met, even if it means shifting secondary individual goals.
(Proactive Mentorship and Support Networks) I am a firm believer in keeping close mentors and a professional support network. I don’t wait for a crisis to build these relationships. By maintaining regular contact with mentors, I have a ‘ready-to-go’ sounding board when stress hits. This means I can get high-level advice or a second opinion quickly, without needing a full debrief of the situation, allowing for faster decision-making under pressure.

In short, I manage stress by converting it into structured team action. This ensures that the quality of our evidence remains high, even when the timeline is short.

I’ve had a very rewarding journey in my current position, and I am proud of the milestones our team has achieved. However, I have reached a professional ceiling where the nature of the work no longer aligns with where I want to make an impact. I am moving toward this role for three main reasons:

Moving from Advice to Implementation and Tracking In consultancy, you often advise up to a certain point, but because there is sometimes a lack of regulatory follow-through on proposals, it is difficult to ensure those suggestions have a sustained, long-term life. I no longer want to just ‘drop’ a project and move to the next; I want to be part of an institution that has the mandate for the long-term monitoring and tracking of those initiatives. I want to see the evidence loop close.
Seeking a Long-Term Institutional Vision I am looking for a professional environment with a 10- or 20-year horizon, rather than a 6-month project cycle. The EEA’s mission to provide the evidence base for the European Green Deal offers that stability and vision. I want to dedicate my skills to one cohesive, long-term plan where the data I architect today informs policy assessments a decade from now.
Giving Back and Team Growth I leave my current role on excellent terms. I’ve learned an immense amount, built lasting professional relationships, and found great fulfillment in up-skilling my colleagues and mentoring junior researchers. However, to continue my own growth as an expert in environmental health and data architecture, I need to be in a place where the scale of the challenge matches the scale of the European mission.

Closing Statement: Essentially, I’m not running away from my current role; I am running toward the responsibility and the long-term accountability that comes with being an Expert at the EEA.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Data visualisation plays a crucial role in modern decision-making by transforming complex datasets into accessible visual narratives. In an era where data-driven decisions shape industries, effective visualisations help stakeholders quickly grasp insights and patterns, leading to informed and strategic choices.By turning abstract numbers into visual stories, data visualisation enhances understanding, fosters communication, and drives impactful actions.






Tip



In this session we will mostly focus on non-spatial visualisation, but many of the principles also apply to the times when you will be creating maps to be part of your stories.




The main purposes of enhancing your narrative with data can be categorised into three key areas:

Facilitating quick understanding of complex information.
Identifying patterns, trends, and outliers.
Guiding decision-makers towards strategic actions aligned with your objectives.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Tools and Technologies
Selecting the right tool for the job involves considering several factors, including how you plan to share the visualisations, the need for ongoing maintenance, and your own level of expertise. If the data is likely to change frequently, choosing a tool that supports dynamic updates or easy revisions is crucial. Additionally, the way you share your visualisations—whether through static reports, interactive dashboards, or embedded in web pages—will influence the tool selection. Finally, your own proficiency and familiarity with the tool should be taken into account to ensure efficiency and effectiveness in creating impactful visualisations.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Exploring vs. Presenting

“Don’t run before you can walk”

Start simple and gradually build complexity. In data visualisation, it’s tempting to jump straight to advanced tools or sophisticated designs, but this can lead to confusion and inefficiency if the basics are not well understood. Begin with simple exploratory analyses to understand your data, then progressively refine and enhance your visualisations as your message becomes clearer and your narrative more defined.


Exploratory data visualisation
is about discovering insights, identifying patterns, and asking new questions. It is most useful during the initial stages of data analysis when the goal is to understand the data and its structure. At this stage, it’s not about perfection but about exploration and iteration.



Explanatory data visualisation
on the other hand, is about communicating a specific message or insight clearly to an audience. It involves polishing the visualisation, ensuring accuracy, and crafting a narrative that guides the viewer to the intended conclusion.


Learning when to switch from exploration to presentation is key to managing efforts effectively. Investing time in refining and polishing a visualisation is only worthwhile once the message is clear and impactful.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Principles of Data Visualisation

Gestalt Principles
The Gestalt principles originate from a psychological theory developed by German psychologists in the early 20th century. These principles explain how humans naturally perceive visual elements as organized patterns or wholes, rather than as separate components (see Wagemans 2012). In data visualisation, Gestalt principles help designers arrange information in a way that is easily understood and visually appealing. By leveraging these principles, data visualisations can guide viewers to see relationships, hierarchies, and narratives within the data more intuitively.








Principle
Description
Example




Proximity
Elements that are close to each other are perceived as a group.



Similarity
Items that share visual characteristics are seen as related.



Continuity
The eye follows lines and curves smoothly without abrupt changes.



Closure
Incomplete shapes are perceived as complete wholes.



Connectedness
Items connected by lines or other visual cues are seen as related.



Colour
Utilises hues and shades to convey meaning and hierarchy.



White Space
Strategic use of empty space to enhance readability and focus.




These (and many other) principles guide visual perception and interpretation by leveraging the brain’s natural tendencies to group similar elements, follow continuous lines, and fill in gaps to perceive complete shapes. By applying these principles, designers can direct the viewer’s attention, create visual hierarchies, and improve the overall user experience. This strategic arrangement of visual elements not only enhances comprehension but also makes complex data more approachable and meaningful.


Choosing the Right Chart
Matching data types to the most effective visualisation is essential for conveying the intended message clearly and accurately. Different types of data—such as categorical, numerical, and temporal data—require different visualisation approaches to effectively highlight patterns, trends, and relationships.

Categorical data, which represents discrete groups or categories, is best displayed using bar charts, pie charts, or stacked column charts for comparing proportions or frequencies.
Numerical data, especially when showing distributions or relationships, is effectively visualised through histograms, scatter plots, or line graphs.
Temporal data, which involves time series or sequences, is well-suited to line charts or area charts to show trends over time.

Selecting the right chart type enhances the narrative and helps the audience interpret the data more intuitively.
NYTimes Visual Vocabulary is a comprehensive guide for matching data types to appropriate chart styles.



NYTimes Chart Doctor Poster








TipAim for…




Clarity and simplicity: Avoid clutter and focus on the message.
Accuracy and integrity: Represent data truthfully.
Aesthetics and engagement: Use colors, fonts, and layouts strategically.









WarningCommon Pitfalls




Misleading graphs (e.g., truncated axes, improper scaling).
Overcomplicating with too much information.
Choosing the wrong type of visualisation for the data.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Final thoughts
As the field continues to evolve, it is crucial to stay curious and experiment with new tools and techniques. Exploring different visualisation methods can inspire creativity and enhance your storytelling abilities. Today’s session is design to start visualising data today and adopt a flexible mindset for continuous improvement.
